turns.speaker: KELLY
turns.text: Her name's Hannah.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Is that Jango?

turns.speaker: KELLY
turns.text: No, this is Jack.  Jango was hit by a UPS truck.  Can you believe it?

turns.speaker: KELLY
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: That's my sea anchor.  My second one. Made it out of part of the sail.  It keeps you from capsizing in a storm.  In theory.  And this, this I used to collect water. About half a cup a day.

turns.speaker: KELLY
turns.text: All that time I waited to go on a cruise, and you went without me.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Yeah, well...couldn't be helped.

turns.speaker: KELLY
turns.text: What's that, written on the sail?

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: My epitaph.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: There was a coffin?

turns.speaker: KELLY
turns.text: Yeah, coffin, headstone, the whole thing.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: What was inside?

turns.speaker: KELLY
turns.text: Your calendar, your cell phone, your whoo pig sooey hat, some pictures of that ketch you wanted.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: That about sums it up.

turns.speaker: KELLY
turns.text: Maybe now's when you tell me about it.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: The plane went down.  My friends died.  I washed up on an island.  Then I found these barrels, built the raft, and here I am.

turns.speaker: KELLY
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: The tide came in, the tide went out.  I survived.  That's the headline.  I survived.

turns.speaker: KELLY
turns.text: Don't overwhelm me with the details.  You know how I hate that.

turns.speaker: KELLY
turns.text: Come on.  Try.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Cliches, mainly.  Don't take anyone for granted.  Don't sweat the small stuff. Live each day like it's your last.

turns.speaker: KELLY
turns.text: So simple to say, so hard to do.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Not when you have no choice.

turns.speaker: KELLY
turns.text: You hated being alone.  Couldn't stand it.  Busy every minute.  Always plugged into something.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: I didn't know what really being alone was.  No one back here does.

turns.speaker: KELLY
turns.text: This is so unfair.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: That's what I told the fish I caught. But I ate them anyway.

turns.speaker: KELLY
turns.text: You okay?

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Great.  Really.

turns.speaker: KELLY
turns.text: What will you do?

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: I don't know.  I really don't know.

turns.speaker: KELLY
turns.text: I've got to get back to Memphis. Hannah's babysitter has finals.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: It means a lot...that you came.

turns.speaker: KELLY
turns.text: I had to come.  To be sure you were okay.

turns.speaker: KELLY
turns.text: I love you, Chuck.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: You too.

turns.speaker: KELLY
turns.text: I'm so glad you're alive.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: I need the latest PDRs on St. Petersburg.

turns.speaker: LESLIE
turns.text: And how was your Christmas?

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Terrific.  Yours?

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: When's the next Jumbo?

turns.speaker: LESLIE
turns.text: The regular flight is scheduled for oh three hundred tomorrow.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Anything else?

turns.speaker: LESLIE
turns.text: There's a sweep leaving Memphis in an hour, goes through Sydney.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: My favorite doctor.  What's the verdict?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Under the circumstances your overall health is good.  Those salt water boils you picked up on the raft are ulcerated, but they're healing nicely.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Sorry...sorry... Why do my joints still ache?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Dehydration.  Vitamin deficiency. Protein deficiency.  Any or all of the above.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: All I ate was fish.  That's solid protein.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Protein digestion is very costly in water usage.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Which I didn't have.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And fish are very low in fat, which is energy inefficient.  So you're going to burn up your own cells no matter how much you eat.  Luckily you ate the eyes and pancreas, which contain some Vitamin C, so you didn't get scurvy.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: I am one lucky guy.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Your body chemistry and your exposure to the elements would normally lead to irritability, depression, anxiety, periods of self-reproach.  It's almost like schizophrenia.  Different sides of your personality might come to life, speak out, act out.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: But all that's behind me.  I'm fine now.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: If you say you are.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: I most definitely say I am.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Doctor Hegel tells me he discussed the Vietnam POW syndrome with you.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Yes, yes he did.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: You are aware of the potential disruptiveness on your loved ones when you return to your old life?

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Not to mention on me.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Doc, I'm not on the island.  I'm not on the raft.  I'm alive.  I'm so glad to be back, I can't tell you.  I just want out of here.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Well, when that IV runs out, you're through with us.  Just the dentist tomorrow.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Need some help?

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: You bet I do.  High tide comes right up to this road.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: You're not out of Pascagoula, are you?

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: I used to drive one of those.  A long time ago.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: Hey, once a driver, always a driver.  You want a lift?  I've just got one more pickup.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: DRIVER
turns.text: You're Chuck Noland.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Bless us O Lord, and these thy gifts, which we are about to receive, from thou bounty, through Christ the Lord.  Amen.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Let's eat.

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Thought you were going to bring her.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: So did I.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: But chickens?

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Sixty three pounds consumed per capita, up from twenty seven in 1960.  Going to pass beef.  Chicken's global.  No religious taboos.  You don't see your Hindus and your Muslims boycotting poultry.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: True enough.  No sacred chickens nowhere, so far as I know.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: ROGER
turns.text: Come on down to the plant.  It's state of the art.  We're doing for chickens what FedEx did for the delivery business.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Just don't count 'em before they hatch.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: What happened to your pants?

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Mom, meet Jango.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: It seemed like she had such a good time last time.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: It's nothing you did, Mom, believe me.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Look, I help take care of the place.  You got my check, didn't you Mom?

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: That new roof, that's your doing.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Mom, this is a farm.  We've got real strawberries growing outside, we've got real cream.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Oh no, the prodigal son's home.  We bring out the store bought.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Maybe I should take a few days off. Roger's working now, you could use some help around here...

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Don't you even think about it.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: The place is falling apart.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: I'm doing fine.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Doing great, Mom, don't worry about me.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: There's settled folks, and there's nomads.  You're just not a settled folk. You never belonged here.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: When'd you start working here?

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Roger got me on.  I wasn't doing anything, and -- but you're back, you're really back.  I would have come to Memphis, but --

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: I wanted to come here.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: I've got all this back pay coming.  Why don't you let me get you a place in town?

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: This is my home.  I'm part of the wallpaper.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: What a journey you've had.  It seems more than a person should have to bear.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: The tide saved me, Mom.  I lived by it. I'm just wondering where it will take me next.

turns.speaker: TECHNICIAN
turns.text: Trying.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Kamal, you're breaking up.  Can you hear us?

turns.speaker: TECHNICIAN
turns.text: Okay.  After three years the PTR reverts to tape storage, which is okay because we access it through the CPC.  Here it is.  Ten packages from the same sender.  Baku. Delhi.  St. Petersburg.  The guy was a real road warrior.  This package was Kuala Lampur.  No activity in his account after this package.  No forwarding addresses after K.L.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: What about the sender?

turns.speaker: TECHNICIAN
turns.text: Sure.  Bettina Peterson.  Marfa, Texas. Let's run a current check.

turns.speaker: TECHNICIAN
turns.text: Hmmm.  Durango, Colorado; Asheville, North Carolina, then...canceled her account.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Can you find her?

turns.speaker: TECHNICIAN
turns.text: You're looking at a Level III search. For your Level III, you gotta have E-4 authorization.  I don't have it.

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: Kamal is not here.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Who is this?  Where is Kamal?

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: It is Ibrim, I, I am a sorter.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: What's going on down there?

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: Kamal is not here.  We are very defused.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Who's in charge then, where is Chinn?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: What do you expect, from the guy who stole a kid's bicycle when his truck broke down?

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Borrowed.  I borrowed it.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: How'd it go?

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Great.  Terrific.  The good guys won one for a change.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: You what?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: It was fifteen minutes late.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: I checked the weather, you had the jet stream, you could have made it up.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: But I might not have.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Jesus.  I got it working... You have no idea how hard it was... They're finally a team...

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: I'm touched.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: You fucked us over.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: The point of FedEx, as I understand it, is to make the damn connection.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: I was making a point.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: What?  Let Paris hold its plane?  Let Memphis take care of it?  Let somebody down the line clean up your mess?

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Every person counts, every package counts, that's my point.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: You know what your problem is?  You just see the packages in front of you.  You don't see the big picture.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Baloney.  I do see the damn "big picture."

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: I didn't know we had sailboats.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: It's a ketch Kelly and I had chartered.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: For all those vacation days you got coming.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: And never take.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Look, I'm sorry about your plane.  But I couldn't risk being late into Memphis.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Forget it.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: You know General McLelland, he wouldn't attack unless he had everything just right.  Finally Abe Lincoln came to him and said, General, if you're not going to use my army, could I borrow it for a while?  So he gave it to Grant and Grant just said, let's go.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: I'm from Arkansas.  Tell me a story with Robert E. Lee in it and maybe I'll pay attention.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: We're warriors, not desk jockeys.  We've got to be bold.  You always want all your ducks lined up.  But nothing's 100 percent.  It's always 60-40, maybe 51-49. Hell, I'd take 40-60.  Then roll the dice.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: That's why you're a gambling man.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: That's why I'm running foreign and you're not.  That's why you're not married and I am.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: For the third time.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Take the plunge, admit your mistakes, move on to tomorrow.  That's FedEx, that's women, that's life.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: You are one sick fucker.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: I'm trying to help you here.  There's Warsaw, there's this --

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: This was nothing like Warsaw.  I held the truck then minutes, it's not that big a deal.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: A hundred rubles St. Petersburg hits 95 percent in a month.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Ninety five percent?  Just give me the money now.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Talk is cheap.  Are we on or not?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: We're on.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Malaysia's tanking.  We're meeting in ten in operations.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Right.  Get me everything on Indonesia, New Guinea, all the way to Australia.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Stan, it's Chuck...Chuck Noland...

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: God damn!  God damn!  Chuck, it's you!

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: It's me.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: You're fucking dead!

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: I'm most definitely not dead.  And as I recall, you're the sick fucker.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: I beat the odds!

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: You beat 'em to shit, pal!  Jesus!

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: This is Amber.  Her boyfriend lost his foot in a shark attack.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: How about we go somewhere else?

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Want to see my raft?

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: This stinks really bad.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: You should have smelled me.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Cool ropes.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: I braided them.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Must have taken a hell of a long time.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Time I had lots of.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: You were how long on this?

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Forty-three days.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: When I first showed up, I thought you'd lost your fucking marbles.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: I never thought it would end.  Then it did.  It was so great to be saved, I couldn't stop laughing.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: To Wilson.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: To Wilson.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: You've been over the line and you came back.  You've been saved, hallelujah!

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Hallelujah.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: I'm serious.  The burning bush, the big picture, the words in neon...

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: What's it all about?  It's about being so thirsty you'd crush a fish's backbone to suck out the spinal fluid -- that's what it's about.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: To life.  Fuck 'em if they can't take a joke.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: To life.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: That's all there is.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Believe me I know.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Digital laser readers.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Digital laser readers.  Wow.  Terrific.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Take your time.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: That's what it's about.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Being patient.  Don't rush things.  I get it.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Not just that.  Take your time.  Use it. Live it.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Deep, real deep.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: What, then?

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Deliver this package.  Then, I dunno.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: You want that delivered, we'll deliver it.  That's what we do.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: I need to do it.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: Finish what you started.  You haven't changed, Chuck.  It's still you.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Thanks.  For everything.

turns.speaker: STAN
turns.text: No sweat.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: Permission to come aboard, sir.

turns.speaker: CHUCK/CAPTAIN
turns.text: Permission granted.

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: May I ask, where are you bound?

turns.speaker: CHUCK/CAPTAIN
turns.text: San Francisco.  And you?

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: As it happens, I'm headed for Frisco myself.

turns.speaker: CHUCK/CAPTAIN
turns.text: Would you do us the honor of joining us? We're just sitting down at mess.  Pork chops and gravy, cranberries, baked potatoes with all the trimmings, fresh- baked bread, apple pie...

turns.speaker: CHUCK
turns.text: No please, join me.  Some sundried fish strips, a few eyeballs, some gills to munch on.

turns.speaker: ANGELA
turns.text: Only if you can afford it.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Try to think of nothing, Dorothy.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: It's not ergot, it's not pituitary extract, it's not oil of rue...

turns.speaker: ANGELA
turns.text: It claims to restore monthly regularity.

turns.speaker: ANGELA
turns.text: Wilbur, the adopting couple is waiting in your office.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Life is waiting.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: I was dreaming about you. How beautiful you were!

turns.speaker: ANGELA
turns.text: You weren't dreaming about me.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: I was!

turns.speaker: ANGELA
turns.text: Then I wasn't beautiful.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: You were! You *are*! It was fantastic.

turns.speaker: ANGELA
turns.text: It was just the ether, Wilbur...

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: They want to replace me! The Board of Trustees wants to *replace* me!

turns.speaker: ANGELA
turns.text: They just want you to hire some new help.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Some new *things* would be useful. I don't need any "new help."

turns.speaker: ANGELA
turns.text: He'll need clothes... some money...

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Let him try to *make* some money! That's part of "seeing the world," isn't it?

turns.speaker: ANGELA
turns.text: Oh, just stop it! You knew this was going to happen. He's a young man.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: He's still a boy--out in the world, he's still a boy.

turns.speaker: ANGELA
turns.text: Just find him some clothes, Wilbur. He could use some clothes.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: He is a goddamn psychiatrist--of *course* he wants to "help"! He'd be happy if he could help *commit* me!

turns.speaker: ANGELA
turns.text: It's that Mrs. Goodhall you have to be careful of, Wilbur.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: One has to be more than "careful" of Mrs. Goodhall--she has sufficient Christian zeal to start her own country! I'd like to give her a little ether.

turns.speaker: ANGELA
turns.text: This is *your* life story, Wilbur! You just changed the dates!

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: "An internship and two years of training at the Boston Lying-in, South End Branch. For his age, he was judged an accomplished gynecological obstetrical surgeon; he is also experienced in pediatric care..."

turns.speaker: ANGELA
turns.text: You *invented* him! You've completely made his up!

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Don't you understand? The board is going to *replace* me! That's what the "new blood" is *for*!

turns.speaker: ANGELA
turns.text: These *credentials* are against the law!

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: We all know who trained Homer--his credentials are as good as mine are. Don't you be holy to me about the *law*! What has the law done for any of us here?

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: Oh my, yes! This is a *far* superior taste--and crisp, too! You know, so many apples are disappointingly mealy. I wonder of most of the apples in my life weren't meant for pies!

turns.speaker: ANGELA
turns.text: Wilbur, he picked them for us himself...

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: You don't find it depressing that Homer Wells is picking apples?

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: I suppose it wouldn't hurt to *meet* him. What's his name again?

turns.speaker: ANGELA
turns.text: Dr. Homer Wells.

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: I just hope he won't expect us to say *Grace* all the time.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: He *sniffs* that ether! I've seen him do it!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: It's because he's too tired to sleep. He has to.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: He *smells* like he could put you to sleep!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: He's a doctor, Buster--doctors smell like ether.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: *You're* a doctor, Homer--you don't smell like ether.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I'm *not* a doctor. I haven't been to medical school--I haven't even been to high school!

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: But you've studied with the old man for *years*!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I'm *not* a doctor!

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: I'm sorry, Homer.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: I mean your parents.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I know who you mean. I think about leaving here, but not to find *them*.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Whoever they were, they didn't *do* any of the things parents are supposed to do. Dr. Larch did those things, and Nurse Edna, and Nurse Angela.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Yeah. But sometimes I wish I could meet mine, anyway.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: What for, Buster? What would you do if you met them?

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Uh... I'd like to show them that I can cook, a little.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: You cook very well!

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: And that I can drive a truck!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Better than I can!

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Sometimes I want to meet them so I can kill them. Just sometimes.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Homer, you know I would never kill anyone--you know I wouldn't.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: I think Mary Agnes could kill someone.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I doubt it. She's just an...

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: What's she so emotional about?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I don't know. She got left here, like the rest of us, didn't she?

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: What'd she die of?

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: She died of *secrecy*, she died of *ignorance*...

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: What are you going to tell the little ones?

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: I'll tell them Fuzzy was adopted.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Why would the little ones believe that *anyone* would adopt him?

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: They'll believe it because they want to believe it.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Shouldn't we tell Homer?

turns.speaker: LARCH
turns.text: If Homer wanted to know what was happening here, he could pick up a telephone and call us.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: It's time somebody ate *them*.

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: I was lookin' for Wally's letter. I was gonna show it to Homer...  They made him a captain already-- *Captain* Worthington!

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Daddy, it's a letter to *me*.

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: He mentions Homer, too, you know.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Wally said to say, "Hello."

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: It's gettin' late. I think I'll pack it in.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Good night, Daddy.

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: How about him not needin' the friggin' compass! How about that?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Daddy, *please*...

turns.speaker: RAY
turns.text: Good night, kids. Don't catch cold-- it's gettin' cold already.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Good night, Daddy.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: So, Mrs...

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Candy. Candy Kendall.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: How many months are you?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Two.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Is your family in the apple business, too?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: No, but I work there--I like it. My dad's a lobsterman.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I've never seen a lobster.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I've never seen the ocean, either.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: He's going to be dropping bombs on Mandalay! They're going to be shooting at him!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Where's Mandalay?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: Burma!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Oh...

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: I can't have a baby alone. I don't even know if he's coming back!

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I understand.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: I'm a little worried about the...  ...about how much bleeding is okay.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: It should taper off tomorrow, but it can come back again. You have cramps?  They'll ease up, almost entirely. As long as the bleeding isn't heavy, it's normal.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: I guess I'll see you around the orchards. Thanks for everything.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Sure... I'll see you around.

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: So. Not bored yet?

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: I'm *never* bored! It's all very... different for me... here.

turns.speaker: HOMER
turns.text: Uh... have you been *feeling* okay?

turns.speaker: CANDY
turns.text: When I'm not thinking about Wally. I'm not good at being alone.  Oh, goodness. You meant... yes, I'm fine. I...  ...I don't suppose you've seen a lobster yet.
